fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: Corrections made on theguardian.com on 10 May 2010 • Tories brush off expenses scandal while voters punish Labour in general election was amended because the original mentioned Sylvia Heal's decision not to seek re-election as Labour MP Halesowen and Rowley Regis. This has been deleted as Sylvia Heal was not a focus of criticism for her record of expense claims as an MP, and hence is outside the subject matter of this article. Corrections published in the Guardian on 10 May 2010 • We wrote about the awarding of the Templeton prize to Francisco J Ayala, geneticist, molecular biologist and former Dominican priest. The photo shown with the story on the web page was fine – but on the newspaper page the person pictured was the Spanish writer Francisco Ayala, who died last year aged 103 (Monk turned scientist wins £1m spiritual dimension prize, 6 May, page 5). • Reporting on a controversial Tesco plan to open another store in Bristol, a story said that the supermarket chain "insists there is a demand and argues that 18 Tescos for a city of more than 400,000 people is not excessive". A reader challenged this figure, citing a higher tally on Tesco's website. A Tesco spokesman clarified: "The figure [of 17 existing stores] is based on the number of stores within the Bristol city council boundary. A search using the term Bristol on our store locator will give you 30 results. These include stores located in the neighbouring local authorities – Bath and North East Somerset and South Gloucestershire" (Bristol's Tesco challenge: 17 stores in one hour, 18 March, page 2, G2). • Our review of the Aston Martin Rapide (On the road, 1 May, page 75, Weekend), gave the car's top speed as 118mph. That should have been 188mph. • A background piece – A brief history of Greece, 7 May, page 11, G2 – meant to date the declaration of Greek independence to 25 March 1821, not May.
